revisions.rev:
{{NCAATeamFootballSeason |Year=1966 |Team=Purdue Boilermakers |Image= |Conference= Big Ten Conference |Division= |ShortConference=Big Ten |Record= 9-2 |ConfRecord=6-1 |CoachRank=6 |APRank= 7 |HeadCoach=[[Jack Mollenkopf]] |OffCoach= |DefCoach= |OScheme= |DScheme= |StadiumArena=[[Ross-Ade Stadium]] |Champion=Rose Bowl Champions |BowlTourney={{alternate links|1967 Rose Bowl|Rose Bowl Game|title=Rose Bowl}} |BowlTourneyResult= W 14-13 vs. [[USC Trojans football|USC]] }} {{1966 Big Ten football standings}} The '''1966 Purdue Boilermakers football team''' represented the [[Purdue University]] in the [[1966 college football season]]. The Boilermakers, led by future [[National Football League|NFL]] [[quarterback]] [[Bob Griese]], won the {{alternate links|1967 Rose Bowl|Rose Bowl Game|title=Rose Bowl}}.
==Season== Griese led Purdue to a second place finish in the [[Big Ten Conference]] and the school's first appearance in the {{alternate links|1967 Rose Bowl|Rose Bowl Game|title=Rose Bowl}}, where they defeated [[USC Trojans football|USC]], 14-13. The Boilermakers were actually the runner-ups behind [[1966 Michigan State Spartans football team|Michigan State]], but got the Rose Bowl berth because of the Big Ten's "no-repeat" rule of the time. Griese was a two-time All-American at Purdue and was the runner-up to [[Steve Spurrier]] for the 1966 [[Heisman Trophy]].

==Rivalries== *In the battle for the [[Old Oaken Bucket]], Purdue beat Indiana *In the battle for the [[Purdue Cannon]], Purdue beat Illinois *In the battle for the [[Shillelagh Trophy]], Notre Dame beat Purdue
